message_text: Paper Title: Multi-Agent Motion Planning From Signal Temporal Logic Specifications Paper Abstract: We tackle the challenging problem of multi-agent cooperative motion planning for complex tasks described using signal temporal logic (STL), where robots can have nonlinear and nonholonomic dynamics. Existing methods in multi-agent motion planning, especially those based on discrete abstractions and model predictive control (MPC), suffer from limited scalability with respect to the complexity of the task, the size of the workspace, and the planning horizon. We present a method based on timed waypoints to address this issue. We show that timed waypoints can help abstract nonlinear behaviors of the system as safety envelopes around the reference path defined by those waypoints. Then the search for waypoints satisfying the STL specifications can be inductively encoded as a mixed-integer linear program. The agents following the synthesized timed waypoints have their tasks automatically allocated, and are guaranteed to satisfy the STL specifications while avoiding collisions. We evaluate the algorithm on a wide variety of benchmarks. Results show that it supports multi-agent planning from complex specification over long planning horizons, and significantly outperforms state-of-the-art abstraction-based and MPC-based motion planning methods. The implementation is available at https://github.com/sundw2014/STLPlanning . "contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.) "survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work) task - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding) method - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction) data - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus) artifact - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9) tool - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope) concept - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory) other - Entities that don't fit above categories uses - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks) proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS: - ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work) - CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new) { "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey", "triples": [ { "name": "Wikipedia Article Title", "relation": "uses|proposes", "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other", "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...", "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)" } ] } FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool: CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do. 1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field. 2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation. 3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia. 4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple: - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm") - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes) - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/) - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters 5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py 6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes. When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter: WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"]) This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains. Begin now.

## Nonholonomic Motion

A nonholonomic system in classical mechanics is a physical system with some constraints that are impossible to be cast into the form of holonomic constraints. More specifically, nonholonomic systems are mechanical systems with constraints on their velocity that are not derivable from position constraints.

### Key Characteristics

A system is a nonholonomic system, if and only if all its constraints are Pfaffian, but some are not integrable.(no content)In physics, a nonholonomic system is a system whose state depends on the path taken in order to achieve it.

A classic example is a unit sphere rolling without slipping on a plane, where the configuration space is 5-dimensional (2 for the point of contact, 3 for the orientation), but the no-slip condition restricts the velocity to a 2-dimensional subspace.

### Applications and Related Concepts

In robotics, nonholonomic systems have been studied in the scope of motion planning and feedback linearization for mobile robots.(no content)An upright wheel on a plane is a nonholonomic system with a single Pfaffian constraint.(no content)The Chaplygin sleigh is a simple pedagogical example of a nonholonomic system, consisting of a body that slides frictionlessly on a horizontal plane, with a knife edge that constrains its motion so that the knife slides only longitudinally.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

A system is a nonholonomic system, if and only if all its constraints are Pfaffian, but some are not integrable.(no content)In physics, a nonholonomic system is a system whose state depends on the path taken in order to achieve it.

A classic example is a unit sphere rolling without slipping on a plane, where the configuration space is 5-dimensional (2 for the point of contact, 3 for the orientation), but the no-slip condition restricts the velocity to a 2-dimensional subspace.

### Applications and Related Concepts

In robotics, nonholonomic systems have been studied in the scope of motion planning and feedback linearization for mobile robots.(no content)An upright wheel on a plane is a nonholonomic system with a single Pfaffian constraint.(no content)The Chaplygin sleigh is a simple pedagogical example of a nonholonomic system, consisting of a body that slides frictionlessly on a horizontal plane, with a knife edge that constrains its motion so that the knife slides only longitudinally.

Here are the search results for "Nonlinear dynamics":

## Overview

Nonlinear dynamical systems, describing changes in variables over time, may appear chaotic, unpredictable, or counterintuitive, contrasting with much simpler linear systems.(no content)As nonlinear dynamical equations are difficult to solve, nonlinear systems are commonly approximated by linear equations (linearization), though this works only up to some accuracy and hides interesting phenomena such as solitons, chaos, and singularities.

## Key Characteristics

For nonlinear systems, sensitive dependence on initial conditions is one of the (necessary but not sufficient) conditions for chaotic behavior.(no content)Examples of nonlinear differential equations are the Navier–Stokes equations in fluid dynamics and the Lotka–Volterra equations in biology.

## Applications

The study of dynamical systems has applications to a wide variety of fields such as mathematics, physics, biology, chemistry, engineering, economics, history, and medicine.(no content)The dynamical systems approach to neuroscience is a branch of mathematical biology that utilizes nonlinear dynamics to understand and model the nervous system and its functions.

## Research and Publications

Nonlinear Dynamics, An International Journal of Nonlinear Dynamics and Chaos in Engineering Systems is a monthly scientific journal covering all nonlinear dynamic phenomena associated with mechanical, structural, civil, aeronautical, ocean, electrical, and control systems.

Here are the key findings about multi-agent systems from the search results:

## Definition

A multi-agent system (MAS) is a computerized system composed of multiple interacting intelligent agents.(no content)Multi-agent systems can solve problems that are difficult or impossible for an individual agent or a monolithic system to solve.

## Composition and Types

Multi-agent systems consist of agents and their environment, and typically refer to software agents, though the agents could equally well be robots, humans or human teams.(no content)Agents can be divided into types spanning simple to complex, including passive agents without goals and active agents with simple goals.

## Key Characteristics

Key characteristics include autonomy (agents are at least partially independent and self-aware) and decentralization (no agent is designated as controlling).(no content)Multi-agent systems can manifest self-organisation as well as self-direction and other control paradigms and related complex behaviors even when the individual strategies of all their agents are simple.

## Recent Developments

With advancements in large language models (LLMs), LLM-based multi-agent systems have emerged as a new area of research, enabling more sophisticated interactions and coordination among agents.

## Applications

Applications where multi-agent systems research may deliver an appropriate approach include online trading, disaster response, target surveillance and social structure modelling.

I found comprehensive information about collision avoidance systems across multiple domains. Here's a summary of the key results:

## Overview

Collision avoidance in transportation is the maintenance of systems and practices designed to prevent vehicles (such as aircraft, motor vehicles, ships, cranes and trains) from colliding with each other.

## Applications by Domain

**Aviation:** A traffic alert and collision avoidance system (TCAS), also known as an Airborne Collision Avoidance System (ACAS), is an aircraft collision avoidance system designed to reduce the incidence of mid-air collision between aircraft.

**Automotive:** A collision avoidance system (CAS), also known as a pre-crash system, forward collision warning system (FCW), or collision mitigation system, is an advanced driver-assistance system designed to prevent or reduce the severity of a collision.

**Maritime:** Maritime Collision Avoidance Systems (MCAS) are integrated technologies used to prevent collisions and groundings at sea by enhancing vessel situational awareness.

**Spacecraft:** Spacecraft collision avoidance is the implementation and study of processes minimizing the chance of orbiting spacecraft inadvertently colliding with other orbiting objects.

**Networking:** In computer networking and telecommunication, collision-avoidance methods try to avoid resource contention by attempting to avoid simultaneous attempts to access the same resource.

**Maritime:** Maritime Collision Avoidance Systems (MCAS) are integrated technologies used to prevent collisions and groundings at sea by enhancing vessel situational awareness.

Links: [{"title":"Model predictive control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Model_predictive_control"},{"title":"Stochastic control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stochastic_control"},{"title":"Predictive control of switching power converters - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Predictive_control_of_switching_power_converters"},{"title":"System identification - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/System_identification"},{"title":"Linear–quadratic regulator - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Linear-quadratic_regulator"},{"title":"Hardware stress test - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hardware_stress_test"},{"title":"Linear–quadratic–Gaussian control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Linear-quadratic-Gaussian_control"},{"title":"Intermittent control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Intermittent_control"}]

Based on the search results, here's a comprehensive overview of Model Predictive Control:

## Definition and Overview

Model predictive control (MPC) is an advanced method of process control that is used to control a process while satisfying a set of constraints.(no content)Model predictive controllers rely on dynamic models of the process, most often linear empirical models obtained by system identification.

## Key Characteristics

MPC uses the current plant measurements, the current dynamic state of the process, the MPC models, and the process variable targets and limits to calculate future changes in the dependent variables, with these changes calculated to hold the dependent variables close to target while honoring constraints on both independent and dependent variables.(no content)The MPC typically sends out only the first change in each independent variable to be implemented, and repeats the calculation when the next change is required.

## Historical Applications

It has been in use in the process industries in chemical plants and oil refineries since the 1980s.(no content)In recent years it has also been used in power system balancing models and in power electronics.

## Linear vs. Nonlinear MPC

Linear MPC approaches are used in the majority of applications with the feedback mechanism of the MPC compensating for prediction errors due to structural mismatch between the model and the process.(no content)The process can be controlled with nonlinear MPC that uses a nonlinear model directly in the control application.

Based on the search results, here's information about Signal Temporal Logic (STL):

Signal Temporal Logic (STL) is a form of temporal logic, which is a branch of formal logic used in computer science. Temporal logic is any system of rules and symbolism for representing and reasoning about propositions qualified in terms of time.

While the search results mention STL as one of several temporal logic variants (alongside Linear Temporal Logic, Metric Temporal Logic, and others), they don't provide detailed specifics about STL itself in the snippets returned. However, the results do indicate that temporal logics like STL are used in contexts involving reasoning about systems and signals over time.

In model checking, a signal or timed state sequence is an extension of the notion of words in a formal language, in which letters are continuously emitted. This concept is related to how STL would be applied—working with continuous signals rather than discrete states.

Temporal logic has found an important application in formal verification, where it is used to state requirements of hardware or software systems, which is also a key application area for Signal Temporal Logic.

If you need more specific technical details about STL's syntax, semantics, or particular applications, I'd be happy to search for more targeted information.

Web search results for query: "Mixed-integer linear programming"

Links: [{"title":"Integer programming - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Integer_programming"},{"title":"Linear programming - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Linear_programming"},{"title":"Linear programming relaxation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Linear_programming_relaxation"},{"title":"lp_solve - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lp_solve"},{"title":"Integer linear programming - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/?title=Integer_linear_programming&redirect=no"}]

Based on the search results, here's information about Mixed-Integer Linear Programming:

## Definition

Mixed-integer linear programming (MIP or MILP) is a problem where only some of the unknown variables are required to be integers, while others can be continuous variables.

## Problem Characteristics

If some decision variables are not discrete, the problem is known as a mixed-integer programming problem. Mixed-integer linear programming is a technique for the optimization of a linear objective function, subject to linear equality and linear inequality constraints.

## Applications

Mixed-integer programming has many applications in industrial productions, including job-shop modelling. Other practical applications include:

- Agricultural production planning involving determining production yield for several crops that can share resources (such as land, labor, capital, seeds, fertilizer) with the objective to maximize total production without exceeding available resources
- Service and vehicle scheduling in transportation networks, such as assigning buses or subways to individual routes while meeting timetables and equipping them with drivers

## Solution Methods

Cutting plane methods work by solving the linear programming relaxation and then adding linear constraints that drive the solution towards being integer without excluding any integer feasible points. Another class of algorithms are variants of the branch and bound method, such as the branch and cut method that combines both branch and bound and cutting plane methods.

Links: [{"title":"Integer programming - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Integer_programming"},{"title":"Linear programming - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Linear_programming"},{"title":"Linear programming relaxation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Linear_programming_relaxation"},{"title":"lp_solve - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lp_solve"},{"title":"Integer linear programming - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/?title=Integer_linear_programming&redirect=no"}]

Based on the search results, here's information about Mixed-Integer Linear Programming:

## Definition

Mixed-integer linear programming (MIP or MILP) is a problem where only some of the unknown variables are required to be integers, while others can be continuous variables.

## Problem Characteristics

If some decision variables are not discrete, the problem is known as a mixed-integer programming problem. Mixed-integer linear programming is a technique for the optimization of a linear objective function, subject to linear equality and linear inequality constraints.

## Applications

Mixed-integer programming has many applications in industrial productions, including job-shop modelling. Other practical applications include:

- Agricultural production planning involving determining production yield for several crops that can share resources (such as land, labor, capital, seeds, fertilizer) with the objective to maximize total production without exceeding available resources
- Service and vehicle scheduling in transportation networks, such as assigning buses or subways to individual routes while meeting timetables and equipping them with drivers

## Solution Methods

Cutting plane methods work by solving the linear programming relaxation and then adding linear constraints that drive the solution towards being integer without excluding any integer feasible points. Another class of algorithms are variants of the branch and bound method, such as the branch and cut method that combines both branch and bound and cutting plane methods.

I've successfully performed a web search for "Motion planning robotics." Here's a summary of what was found:

## Overview

Motion planning (also path planning or the navigation problem) is a computational problem to find a sequence of valid configurations that moves the object from the source to destination.(no content)The term is used in computational geometry, computer animation, robotics and computer games.

## Key Problem Definition

A basic motion planning problem is to compute a continuous path that connects a start configuration S and a goal configuration G, while avoiding collision with known obstacles.

## Main Approaches

The search results reveal several important algorithms and techniques:

1. **Sampling-based Algorithms**: Sampling-based algorithms are currently considered state-of-the-art for motion planning in high-dimensional spaces, and have been applied to problems which have dozens or even hundreds of dimensions (robotic manipulators, biological molecules, animated digital characters, and legged robots).

2. **Grid-based Approaches**: Grid-based approaches overlay a grid on configuration space and assume each configuration is identified with a grid point. At each grid point, the robot is allowed to move to adjacent grid points as long as the line between them is completely contained within Cfree. Search algorithms (like A*) are used to find a path from the start to the goal.

## Real-World Applications

Motion planning has several robotics applications, such as autonomy, automation, and robot design in CAD software, as well as applications in other fields, such as animating digital characters, video game, architectural design, robotic surgery, and the study of biological molecules.

1. [completed] Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. [completed] List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. [completed] For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. [in_progress] Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple: name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm"), relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes), entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other, wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/), relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. [pending] Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. [pending] If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.
